It is most likely not going to affect the short term price of oil at all. It may affect the medium term price (5-8 year). Then  again it depends on the type of alternate fuel solution.

The reason is: Technology needs to be built to produce it alternate energy, and technology needs to be built to use it. Takes time to fund it. Then there is a transition period for people to be convinced to switch to alternative means. All this takes time beyond the short term.
in the below example I gave. The reason investors suddenly pull out is due to market psychology like sal said. This happens a LOT.
The sad truth is. If people make a habit of it to withdraw money and pay instead of paying by card.. it can actually drive down oil prices...

here is an example.
- Investors speculate on a oil exploration + drilling company. Now they have funds to drill oil.

- Investors suddenly decide to sell their investments in the company. Now they are under funded. 

- So to make up the needed money for drilling they will increase their crude oil price.

- This in a chain reaction will will cause the consumer price of oil to raise.

(this is a very simple example)
How can "speculation" drive real prices?

@GodDamnit7711 Free market healthcare is a massive source of market failure so the US government requires insurers to insure unprofitable consumers, basically. As such the insurers and healthcare companies have to charge ridiculous amounts to cover their very high spendings due to unhealthy lifestyle in the US, and since they have the profit incentive (something I don't believe healthcare should have), they realise that demand is pretty much static and they can charge whatever they want.

@GodDamnit7711 part 2) and it gets even worse! even if the person in need of drug x is well to do, there is still no limit imposed on what the company can charge since a ludicrously high price will rob the person of so much wealth that he can then qualify for medicaid! Of course patents are enforced by the state and if a patent prevents competition what will a drug company be willing to charge for a drug that is necessary to save someones life? 100% of what that person is able to pay.
@GodDamnit7711 I would check out the AMA if you want to see a large part of it.

@GodDamnit7711 im not sal but i can still try to answer it. government mandates licensing, forces hospitals to accept patients who have no money, and creates such a web of red tape so complex armies of compliance officers must be employed to untangle it, this increases cost which can only be passed on to consumers. medicare and medicaid create a moral hazard which allows hospitals to charge arbitrarily high prices while experiencing minimal reduction in demand.

@SpecialGuy21 Yes, you could blame Bush for an unnecessary war that caused stress in the market which caused prices to rise.
